newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria's Socialists reel as opposition wins poll.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria's Socialists reel as opposition wins poll.

text.p: Opposition candidate Petar Stoyanov swept to a decisive victory in Bulgaria's presidential election in what newspapers hailed on Monday as a powerful blow to the governing Socialist Party.

With most votes counted, official preliminary results gave the pro-reform lawyer of the anti-communist Union of Democratic Forces (UDF) 60 percent of the vote to Socialist Culture Minister Ivan Marazov's 40 percent.

Although the president is a largely ceremonial figure with limited powers, the scale of Stoyanov's victory threw the government onto the defensive and Prime Minister Zhan Videnov, battling a deep economic crisis, promised to take note.
Videnov, in power for nearly two years, said on Sunday a party congress could be held as early as January and did not rule out cabinet changes.
"Petar Stoyanov's crushing victory is the biggest blow for Zhan Videnov since he became prime minister. He has to resign," said the daily Standart in a front-page editorial.
"Bulgarians have decisively rejected a handful of incompetent officials who have pushed our country to the back of Europe's queue and have driven citizens to the bottom."

Videnov, often criticised for his secretive and authoritarian style of government, has presided over a big drop in living standards as Bulgaria struggles to meet huge foreign debt payments and kickstart its sluggish reform programme.
"Bulgarians have declared their desire for change, even though the institution of president lacks any real power to alter the country's course," said the Novinar newspaper.

Outgoing president Zhelyu Zhelev, also a liberal who did not stand for reelection, has frequently wielded his veto over Socialist legislation, frustrating what he saw as the government's attempts to restore communist era practices.
Like Zhelev, Stoyanov has pledged to bring Bulgaria -- which still looks to Moscow, its historical patron, for guidance -- closer to the European Union and NATO.

Stoyanov was careful on Sunday night to avoid direct criticism of the Socialists and proposed a National Salvation Council of experts and respected public figures to advise the government on how to avert economic collapse.

Neighbouring Romania and Yugoslavia, which also held elections on Sunday, face similar difficulties but Bulgaria has the lowest level of foreign investment among the former communist states of eastern Europe.
Bulgaria has managed to privatise only five percent of state industry since the bloodless overthrow of its communist regime seven years ago this month.

This week Bulgarian officials will be locked in vital talks with a visiting mission of the International Monetary Fund, desperately trying to unblock loans to help tide the country through a winter of expected bread and power shortages.
